Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Situation2: Your I04iend has misunderstood the tone of your text message and replied sounding hurt. You need to call them right now to explain.
Story: It’s Saturday evening, and I’m sprawled on my bed, phone in hand. I remember Mom’s gentle reminder last week: “Just a quick text now and then, honey. We miss you.” I haven’t messaged them yet, so I start typing, “Hey, just checking in. Hope you’re both well.” Before I can hit send, my phone buzzes—a message from Sam. His words are clipped, and I can tell he’s upset. He’s misunderstood my last text, thinking I was annoyed with him. My chest tightens. I know Sam hates unresolved tension; he expects me to call and clear things up right away. But my parents are waiting, probably worrying if I’m okay. I stare at my phone, torn. If I call Sam now, I’ll put off my parents again. If I text my parents first, Sam might stew in his hurt. Both expect me to be there, to communicate, to care. I feel the weight of both roles pressing in, and I can’t decide which to answer first.
